intro: Santiria fasciculata var. puberula, commonly known as the hairy santiria, is a flowering plant native to parts of Southeast Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small white or yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest understories. Its hairy texture, as indicated by the varietal name "puberula," is a distinguishing feature. It is sometimes used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
